Discerning the three kinds of karma, namely, body, speech, and mind
Discerning the four kinds of retribution, namely, black retribution, white retribution, mixed retribution, and neither black nor white retribution

Extensively discerning the mutual arising of afflictions and karma, the meaning of the supreme worldly dharmas being both contaminated and uncontaminated, extensively discerning the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment with nine kinds of names, namely, master, supreme, guide, etc., extensively discerning the ten contemplations, extensively discerning the seven contemplations Chapter 7: KÄÅ›yapa Good man!
Sentient beings contemplate feelings and know that they are all... By severing the combination, feelings are not produced.
Commentary: Saá¹ƒghabhadra says:
Explaining that craving is the cause, if one takes self as pleasure, then craving and attachment arise.
As for the good and evil created by the twelve links of dependent arising, taking birth and death as pleasure, one is unable to be free from it, so it is called the time of feeling.
As for the causes and conditions that give rise to it, next contemplating the causes of feeling, the causes also have causes, from subtle to obvious, clarifying that they can be severed.
Not caused by the birth from a supreme god, the true cause must be obtained.
All arise from the combination of conditions means that when conditions combine, it is neither self nor other, and there is no fixed principal in arising.
This is craving means that pleasant feeling gives rise to craving, and craving gives rise to pleasant feeling, which are mutually causal.
This is in the midst of combination means that because of combination, it is not existent; because combination gives rise to it, it is not nonexistent. If combination is severed, it does not arise.
Baoliang says:

From here below, the six kinds of dharmas are observed, namely feeling, conception, contact, desire, karma, and suffering. Only the dharma of contact has no separate observation, but relies on various gates.
The reason for observing feeling first is that all afflictions arise due to feeling, so the faults of feeling are observed first.
In observing feeling, first the cause of feeling is observed, next the lightness and heaviness of the retribution of feeling is observed, and third, the place where feeling ceases is observed.
The cause of internal and external outflows arises from external objects, and the cause of the exhaustion of outflows arises from the three feelings.
In this way, what is the cause of feeling? Next, the cause of feeling is observed.
From where do such causes and conditions arise? means that various contemplations are in sequence, and they are not born without causes.
Not born from thought refers to the thought of the formless realm of non-perceiving beings, which is a different view held by non-Buddhists.
If there is a cause for this birth, one should first cut off the cause of this feeling.

The cause and condition is the receiver, born from the cause of feeling created by the past extinguished mind.ğŸ”½There is no receiver, because there is no inherent nature of feeling in the cause and condition.
There is also no absence of a receiver, because it exists without being apart from the cause and condition.
Good sons!
The wise one who contemplates the cause up to this point is called pure pure conduct.
According to Seng Liang:
If one does not contemplate the suffering of the effect, then one will not be disgusted with feeling;
Because one cuts off the cause of feeling, one next contemplates the effect.
The cause and condition for attaining liberation means that when pleasure arises, one is bound, and when pleasure ceases, one is liberated.
Cutting off the self and what belongs to the self means knowing that there is no controller.
There is a place of slight extinction means that the three wisdoms eliminate afflictions. Eliminating the coarse through hearing and contemplation is called slight final;
Eliminating the subtle through cultivation wisdom is called final liberation.
Knowing it comes from the eightfold correct path and then cultivating it means the eightfold path without outflows is cultivation wisdom.
Increasing body and mind means the eightfold path heading towards cessation, and increasing what goes against the path.
For what causes and conditions can it increase?
Contact as a cause means contemplating the distant cause through hearing and contemplation, and the proximate cause through cultivation wisdom.
Contemplating the effect below.
Neither illumination nor ignorance refers to contaminated wholesome and indeterminate [dharmas].
Mixed food and craving means being able to cause birth and death to be unceasing.
Baoliang says:
Having finished contemplating the causes, next contemplating the effects is obtaining the three evil painful retributions.
Although these three evil effects are all retributions of the four mental aggregates, they cannot be separated from feeling.
What kind of feeling?
It can act as the cause of craving.
What kind of craving?
It can be the cause of feeling.
This clarifies the meaning of mutual generation. Craving can also be the cause of feeling, and feeling can also be the cause of craving.
Since the observation of the lightness and heaviness of causes and effects is already complete, the third observation of the place of cessation of feeling is next.
If one attains the five faculties headed by faith and accomplishes the two emptinesses, it is called the cessation of little.
Up to the correct observation of the undefiled, it is called the great cessation.
This is the contemplation of the three characteristics of feeling, which are the characteristics of the three feelings.
However, these three feelings can increase the afflictions of body and mind in the aggregate of formations.
For what causes and conditions can they increase? They arise from the three causes of contact.
The first is the contact of ignorance, which is the contact of afflictions.
The second is the contact of clarity, which can give rise to the eightfold correct path of the undefiled.
The third is the contact of neither clarity nor ignorance, which is the worldly good mind.
As such, feeling is also called cause and also called fruit. Arising from contact, it is called fruit. Because it can give rise to feeling, it is also called cause.
Having completed the three approaches to contemplating feeling, we now next contemplate the fruits of craving. Because craving gives rise to, it is necessary to contemplate it.
The wise contemplate craving, which is also of two kinds. Craving with nourishment refers to the four kinds of nourishment.
Craving without nourishment refers to cutting off the four kinds of nourishment and attaining the undefiled.

If one wishes to cut off craving, one must first cut off the cause of feeling. The proximate cause is feeling, and the distant cause is contact. Completely cutting off cause and effect, one attains the eightfold noble path, which is then called pure holy life.
Furthermore, good man!
The wise should contemplate up to the cessation of conceptualization and feeling, which is called liberation.
According to Seng Liang:
The two things that arise from what causes and conditions? Craving and feeling are the root of birth and death. Further contemplating the proximate cause.

Knowing that craving arises from conceptualization means that conceptualization grasps provisional names, and there are degrees of delusion, with the heavier becoming the cause of craving and the lighter becoming the cause of feeling.
Seeing form does not give rise to craving explains the cause of feeling.

Attachment to beauty gives rise to craving for beauty. This is the eye consciousness provisionally seeing form, not yet grasping the provisional through conceptualization. Conceptualization experiences good and bad, and the lighter becomes the cause of feeling.
And when contemplating feeling, one also does not give rise to craving explains the cause of craving.

Feeling arises from delusion. When feeling first experiences good, delusion has not yet arisen. Grasping permanence and bliss eventually leads to craving, and the heavier becomes the cause of craving.
Conceptualization has three types means that the lesser has two types: first, taking small objects, second, abiding for a short time on the object. The same is true up to the immeasurable.
Uncertain means that the distracted mind is uncertain, and also abides for a short time.
The same is true for the coarse concentration of the desire realm.
The formless realm has no form and is not moved by external conditions, abiding in concentration for a long time. How can it be explained?
The cessation of conceptualization and feeling is called liberation. This explains why the Buddha said that conceptualization and feeling are the causes of defilements.
Baoliang said:
The wise should contemplate from where the two things of feeling and craving arise.

Knowing that they arise from conceptualization, this is the second gate below, contemplating conceptualization, which is the characteristics of false dharmas, and is therefore called conceptualization.
All inverted and false conditions cannot accord with the reality of dharmas.
As for the three kinds of conceptualization, if conceptualization imagines a small object, it is called small conceptualization;
if conceptualization imagines a large object, it is called large conceptualization;
if conceptualization imagines an immeasurable object, it is called immeasurable conceptualization.
There is also small conceptualization, referring to the desire realm's lightning-like concentration for those who have not yet entered concentration;
there is also large conceptualization, referring to the concentration of the eight dhyÄna stages for those who have already entered concentration;
there is also immeasurable conceptualization, referring to the ten universal bases.
If the three conceptualizations cease, then feeling ceases. When conceptualization and feeling cease, it is called liberation.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
Extinguishing all dharmas, up to the hearer also understanding and explaining to sentient beings.
Commentary: Seng Liang said:
Understanding dharmas means dharmas are distinct, while sentient beings are general. The general and distinct characteristics are mutually dependent. Explaining one means knowing two.

The mental factors are mutually dependent. Feeling and conceptualization are essential. If feeling and conceptualization can be eliminated, knowing the rest can also be eliminated, and the explanation is also like this.
Those who should be closely associated with only explain the miscellaneous dharmas, and the understanding is also miscellaneous.
Bao Liang said:
Because of this statement, later Subhuti asked:
If the cessation of conceptualization and feeling is explained as liberation, is that so?
The Buddha replied:

The Tathagata sometimes explains sentient beings based on sentient beings. Those who hear and understand are like the previous explanation to Mahakashyapa that when sentient beings cease, the good Dharma also ceases.
It's just that the Dharma is spread by people. If people no longer practice, then the Dharma will not circulate, so the Dharma is clarified using sentient beings.
Based on the Dharma, sentient beings are explained, and those who hear also understand.
As for speaking of sentient beings, it is like speaking to Ä€nanda, saying, If there is a teaching that can give rise to afflictions, then one should not associate with it, which is an evil friend.
If there is a teaching that can give rise to goodness, then one should associate with it, which is a good friend.

Since he has spoken of the teachings that can be associated with and those that cannot be associated with, then people can understand good sentient beings and bad sentient beings based on the teachings, and thus the good can be associated with and the bad cannot be associated with.
Good man!
The TathÄgata, although he speaks of the cessation of conceptualization and feeling... although there are poisonous herbs, there are also wonderful medicines.
Commentary: Seng Liang says:
As for not having conceptualization, distinguishing dharmas with conventional truth is conceptualization.
What is commonly transmitted in the world is called spreading.
Conventional truth has two aspects:
One is principle, the other is inversion.
Taking the broad as the provisional is principle, considering there to be one or many is inversion, and inversion gives rise to attachment.
Bao Liang says:
Although it is said that the two cessations of thought and feeling are explained, it is actually a general explanation of the cessation of all dharmas.
Because thought is caused by contact, next it is observed that contact has two kinds. It causes the afflictions of thought and feeling through ignorance and consciousness;
It causes the cutting off of afflictions and the attainment of liberation through wisdom and consciousness.
Contact is originally based on various gates, so it is not observed separately.
Furthermore, good sons!
The wise observe desire. Although there are poisonous plants, there are also wonderful medicines.
Commentary:
That which is form and sound refers to first observing the causes of desire.
The causes are internal and external. Form and so forth are external, while reaching thought is internal.
Then it gives rise to feeling refers to desire.
Desire is not a separate dharma. Erroneous thought is mostly desire. Pleasure is called feeling.
Evil thoughts arise after the ten evils, which are called the ten evil thoughts.
Despising one's parents refers to the retribution of killing and harming, which is the retribution of rebirth in hell.
Baoliang said:
Next, the third observation of desire.
Desire refers to the five sense objects. It clarifies that the five sense objects are not desire but can give rise to desire. Speaking of the effect in the cause is called desire.

The reason for contemplation is that because of the five sense objects, consciousness arises. Because of attachment to consciousness, conceptualization arises. Because of conceptualization, feeling arises. Because of feeling, craving arises within the aggregate of karmic formations.
However, from the five sense objects up to feeling, all are causes of desire.
But because the faults of consciousness are few, it is not made into a separate gate of contemplation.
Furthermore, good man!
The wise one thus creates three kinds of bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
According to Seng Liang:
Next, one should contemplate karma. The eight sufferings take birth as their basis.
Afflictions and karma combine and then one receives birth.

Next, contemplating karma, receiving, conceptualization, contact, and desire are afflictions. The nature of delusion is all afflictions, distinguished by the differences in beginning, end, lightness, and heaviness. The ability to distinguish is called contact, but there is no separate gate, as it is a cause of conceptualization and feeling.
The first is the karma of birth, the second is the karma of experience. The karma that supports birth is called birth, that which can obtain the retribution of birth is called experience.
Good sons, the two karmas of body and speech are the meaning of creating karma.
The nature of the mind creates, not creating from birth. The body and speech have both.
Because of the cause, it is called karma. The body and speech are not of the nature of creation, but because of the mind, they are given the name.
The correct karma is of the mind, the promised karma is of body and speech. The nature is good and evil, called correct. It is called promised because it accords with others' good and evil.

Because it is emitted first, it is called the mind up to it is called correct is the correct explanation, meaning that what is emitted first is the master, and what accords with others is the promise.
It is the contact of ignorance means that karma can penetrate the four, but in wanting to explain the cause of suffering, it only speaks of ignorance.
Bao Liang said:
The wise one, having contemplated desire, should next contemplate karma. The fourth gate clarifies that feeling, thought, contact, and desire are precisely afflictions.
The afflictions that can create karma are the link of karmic formations in the twelve links of dependent origination.
The afflictions that do not create karma are those that do not create karma that moistens and produces rebirth.
Why is this?
When one first creates karma, one must not have changed one's rebirth, so one has not yet used the afflictions that moisten and produce rebirth.

In this way, the afflictions accompany karmic existence in two ways, namely, creating karma and creating rebirth. It clarifies that the afflictions from beginning to end are inseparable, and they can mutually act as causes and create karma. They can also create karma that produces rebirth, so they come back and take again.
After contemplating karma is finished, one then contemplates the causes, which are the contacts of ignorance.
Because of this ignorant delusion, consciousness grasps at objects and produces karmic formations.
After contemplating the causes is finished, one then contemplates the fruits of retribution obtained from karma.
Those of the highest goodness are reborn in JambudvÄ«pa. This discussion is superior in terms of receiving the Way, different from the teachings of the past.
Although the two teachings are different, each has its own meaning.
The meanings of the other three continents are all different from the past, and these are not further explained.
Good sons!
The wise one who observes in this way the causes of karma up to the fruition of retribution is called pure karma.
According to Seng Liang:
The defilements at the time of creating karma explain the name of karma.
Because of unwholesomeness, the fruition of retribution is suffering.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One, up to although there are poisonous herbs, there are also wonderful medicines.
According to Seng Liang:
This meaning has two aspects: first, it is both fruition and retribution; second, it is only fruition and not retribution.
As for only being fruition and not retribution, fruition is the cause of retribution. This name is general;
using the cause as the cause of retribution, this name is specific.
The contaminated has both, while the uncontaminated has only one.
Good sons, because there is no retribution - karma is named based on retribution, and the experience of suffering and happiness is the direct retribution.
The nature of suffering is black, and the nature of happiness is white. Using happiness to treat suffering is called the antidote. The cessation of suffering and happiness is tranquility.
There are places where retribution is definitely received. Black is in the three evil paths, and white is in the human and heavenly realms.
In Uttarakuru, worldly happiness is supreme, and the happiness of the Way is inferior.
Furthermore, good man!
The wise one, having contemplated karma and afflictions, reaches the suffering that arises from the causes of suffering.
According to Seng Liang:
The two attainments refer to contemplating the two dharmas of suffering that arise together. Nirvana is named after attaining the fruit.
The two fruits are suffering.
Separating from all birth means that birth is the root of suffering, so birth is mentioned first.
Next, contemplating the causes of afflictions means that the four paths, karma, and afflictions are the causes, and the path of suffering is the fruit.
The causes and effects are collectively called the path of existence. The four paths arise from each other, and one cannot discern their sequence.
Bao Liang said:

Having contemplated karma, the wise person next contemplates the fruits obtained from karma and afflictions. The fifth gate contemplates suffering, clarifying that karma and afflictions mutually give rise to suffering.
The causes and conditions of the six destinies are all without the slightest joy, so the sages instruct one to end suffering and cultivate the path.
Good sons!
The wise are able to contemplate in this way, and one should know that this person is able to end all suffering.
Seng Liang says:

Not creating new karma and destroying old karma refers to the twelve links of dependent origination, which are collectively the three kinds of suffering. Seeing the three kinds of suffering destroys all karma.
Contemplating all hells is contemplating the suffering of suffering.
Further contemplating humans and gods is separately contemplating the suffering of change.
Deeply contemplating the various sufferings of the three realms is separately contemplating the suffering of conditioned existence.
The wise, if able to contemplate the eight kinds of suffering, is a summary.
Good sons!
The wise deeply contemplate these eight sufferings, and although there are poisonous herbs, there are also wonderful medicines.
Seng Liang says:
Seeking body and seeking wealth means that the body is inner life and wealth is outer life.
To create karma means to do good and evil.
To increase means to increase good and evil.
Creating karma is creating mental karma.
Creating results is creating physical and verbal karma, which is grasping.
Craving and grasping are names for light and heavy. Light is the cause of heavy, and grasping is the result.
The sutra says, Being close to the five desires is called craving.
Internally and externally greedily seeking is called grasping.
This is understanding the light and heavy.

The condition of craving is grasping, and the condition of grasping is craving. Craving and grasping increase, and next they become the cause of cessation. As the cause of existence, there is increase and decrease, clarifying that they can be eliminated.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One, up to all of them, what are all dharmas?
Commentary:
The eighth praises the virtues of the sutra.
Purity is nirvana, and the cause is practice.

Nirvana and the three dharmas are all causes. There is no dharma that is not a cause. Although it is said that all dharmas are [causes], the meaning is not definite, and the purport has not been revealed, so it is determined.
The root of all good and evil dharmas, using the root to encompass the branches, is also the same as all good and virtuous friends encompassing all pure practices.
Baoliang said:
In the eighth section of the main part, next it clarifies praising the sutra.
If one relies on this practice, one will surely transcend birth and death and accomplish pure pure practices.
The principles clarified in the teachings of the past were not yet correct, and they had not yet been separated from birth and death, so they did not become true pure practices.
Now, within this, there are three praises:
The first generally praises based on the objective realm and wisdom;
The second specifically praises based on the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and the essence of uncontaminated wisdom;
The third praises based on the ten contemplations, taking the meaning of distant assistance and inspiration.
Now that Kasyapa has asked, the Buddha answers that all of them are.
This generally praises based on the objective realm and wisdom.
The realm can give rise to understanding, and wisdom arises for a reason. Therefore, they are generally classified as pure holy conduct.
Although there is this judgment, the meaning is not yet clear. Therefore, KÄÅ›yapa again raises questions about various dharmas:
All dharmas are indeterminate. Which dharma does the TathÄgata now determine to be all?
The Buddha again answers:
The MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra is the treasure store of all dharmas.
Therefore, know that the principle of this sÅ«tra is correct and fully clarifies the six practices, which can give rise to people's faith and wisdom, and quickly lead them out of birth and death.

Therefore, regardless of whether it is that dharma or this dharma, they all arise from nirvÄá¹‡a. Also, based on this realm and wisdom, one attains great nirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, they all attain to be pure holy conduct.
Therefore, the following frequently praises the power and function of this sÅ«tra by doing more than thirty things.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent! Good man... the parents of the buddhas of the present.
According to Seng Liang:
All dharmas refers to the dharma of the sÅ«tras.
It can save the poor and destitute, and is called a treasure.
It is called a treasury because it contains all treasures.
This sutra speaks of buddha-nature and fruition, which can bring one out of birth and death, and is called a treasure.
Speaking of fruition means that there is no dharma that is not permanent, and speaking of cause means that there is no dharma that is not the nature, and is called a treasury.
From the analogy of the great ocean below, it is a treasury, and from the analogy of a fierce wind below, it is a treasure.
Good man!
Therefore, this sutra encompasses all dharmas up to the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
According to Seng Liang:
First, it speaks of the correct cause, and then speaks of the proximate cause.
Bao Liang said:

Above, it has already generally discussed the realm and wisdom. Now, it correctly takes the true pure nature to clarify the understanding of true signlessness, because it is not accompanied by delusions, and therefore it can be called the pure holy life.
Although the five expedient means are similar understanding, the essence is still not free from delusions, and therefore it is not the pure holy life.
Good man!
If one departs from these thirty-seven factors, one will not be able to attain the name of pure holy conduct.
Seng Liang said:
Not speaking of the contaminated as holy conduct means that the thirty-seven factors are of two kinds. Speaking of the uncontaminated, they continue to nirvana and are called practice.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One, therefore it is called pure holy conduct.
Seng Liang said:
Citing the five consciousnesses as being without afflictions and inverted, he decides it.
Not a male giving rise to the thought of a male means that the five consciousnesses apprehend male and female without clarity, not yet forming afflictions;
Not causing them not to be apprehended means that the characteristics of apprehension are inverted, able to give rise to greed and anger.
Good man!
If there are bodhisattvas who contemplate the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, they will ultimately be called great parinirvana.
Seng Liang said:
These nine phrases, the first seven are causes and the last two are effects.
If one knows the distinctions in the functions of causes and effects, then one knows holy conduct.

Bao Liang said:ğŸ”½Here, the Buddha uses the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment to explain the holy conduct of the bodhisattva. The thirty-seven factors are the path of the two vehicles and the bodhisattva. The two vehicles use the thirty-seven factors to attain nirvana. The bodhisattva uses the thirty-seven factors to attain buddhahood. Therefore, the thirty-seven factors are the path of the three vehicles.
The thirty-seven are transformed into nine stages.
Why is it so?
Ordinary people have no understanding and say that the stages are fixed and cannot be explained as many or few.
Now it is clarified that the characteristics of dharmas are not fixed, so they are transformed into nine stages.
Within the nine stages, they are divided only into concentration and wisdom, leaving out precepts.
That which can assist in giving rise to concentration and wisdom is not the essence of the right path, so it is not taken.
Dividing the nine is called the four intentions:
The first has four stages, named according to the upper, middle, and lower grades;
The second has three stages, named according to the skillful activity;
The third stage is named according to the cause of eliminating within its own stage;
The fourth and final stage is named after the fruition.

The first four are named according to gradual increase and progress: The first moment of impurity can provide resources for later understanding, so it is called the root of the first stage of impurity.
The second moment of the uncontaminated mind is called the cause, because it can give rise to the subsequent power and make it stronger.
The third moment of the uncontaminated mind is called the receiver, just as the afflictions arise immediately after the mind of the three feelings.
The meaning here is also the same. Since the understanding and wisdom gradually deepen, it can further attract the arising of subsequent uncontaminated [minds]. Therefore, it is called the receiver.
The fourth moment of the uncontaminated mind is called the augmenter, because this uncontaminated [mind] increases and brightens moment by moment. Therefore, it is given the name augmenter.
Then, from the first abode onwards, they arise in sequence, continuing up to the vajra-mind. In each stage, there are these four dharmas.
Therefore, we know that these four are given their names based on the gradual increase and progress.
Next, there are three dharmas that are given their names based on their functions. It is explained that each stage has these three.
How do we know this?ğŸ”½The main one is called mindfulness, which is able to guard the object.
The guide is called concentration. Because of mindfulness guarding the object, one can peacefully contemplate within the conditions and attain concentration.

Superior is called wisdom means that although concentration can guard the mind and prevent it from scattering, if there is no superior wisdom, or if there is no power to eliminate it, it is called superior because of its superior power.
If that is so, from the first abode and above, up to the vajra stage, in each moment of thought on that stage, there are all these three meanings, but there is no separate mind.
True knowledge is the eighth dharma, which should also be a public function, but the dharma is slightly different.
Why is it so?
True is called liberation. From the first abode, liberation is discussed on that stage, and the ability to eliminate is not discussed.
Now, it clarifies what is eliminated, based on the unconditioned merit obtained by the practitioner, speaking from the side of being unfettered.
Knowing completion is spoken from the ultimate place, taking the essence of nirvana as the purport.
Good sons!
Good desires are the initial arousal of the mind of the Way, and ultimate is the great nirvana.
As explained by Seng Liang:
Those who first give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment wish to save sentient beings and are able to give rise to bodhi.
There are three kinds of desires, which are the roots of the Way.
Some speak of wisdom, some speak of faith. Desires are the basis for giving rise to the aspiration. Touching is the beginning of entering practice, which is called causal conditions.

The faculties are sharp or dull. Sharp wisdom is in the beginning of faith and causal conditions. Therefore, it is said that all evil afflictions are caused by faith in seeking the Dharma. In the end, one will sever afflictions, all of which are the power of faith.
When it comes to the fruition, it is called liberation through faith.

When experiencing, one creates good and evil. When experiencing suffering and pleasant feelings, a good friend explains the Way. If one happily cultivates, then one progresses and embraces the factors of the Way. If one is not happy, then one regresses. Therefore, it is said to be the time of experience.
Giving rise to various afflictions is the explanation.
If one seeks happiness, then it arises. Happiness can then sever it.
Because of good thoughts, although one happily cultivates the Way, one must recognize its antidotes.
One should contemplate well and cultivate what should be cultivated. The factors of the Way increase day by day.
Must be single-minded means one should cultivate diligent cultivation, not thinking of conditions, to accomplish the main practice of concentration.
Able to skillfully distinguish means wisdom is considered supreme.
Mind concentrated seeing the Dharma is called distinguishing, thoroughly understanding is called wisdom.
Initially attaining is called guiding, further illuminating is called supreme.
When realizing liberation means realizing existence and non-existence.
Liberation refers to nirvana with remainder, which is the reality of escaping from birth and death.
Ultimate refers to nirvana without remainder.
Baoliang said:
Previously the Buddha listed the names in order, now he will explain them in five layers in sequence.
The first explanation is:
The root is desire.
Desire refers to the mind of desire and pleasure.
The cause is called clear contact, because it contacts the principle in front, it is called clear contact.
Grasping is called feeling, because it grasps all practices, it is called feeling.
Increasing is called good thought, which is the superior mind that attains the principle.
Guarding the realm without moving, therefore it is called the main name, which is mindfulness.
Guidance is called concentration, which means concentrating the mind on a single object.
Superior is called wisdom, which means destroying afflictions.
True is called liberation, which means the essence of wisdom is without bondage.
Ultimate is called nirvana, which refers to the completion of skillful activity.
From Good desires are the initial arousal of the mind below, the second layer of explanation.
From the first moment of impurity until the attainment of Buddhahood, it is called good desires.
Because of these good desires, one is able to attain Buddhahood, therefore it is called the fundamental.

The Tathagata previously spoke of heedfulness as the basis, now he speaks of desires. It clarifies that desires are the fundamental, and because heedfulness assists in accomplishment, it is called the conditional cause.
If sentient beings are ignorant, they rely on the Buddha to gain understanding, therefore the Buddha is called the fundamental.
Now sentient beings have knowledge and when they realize it themselves, they must rely on the mind of desire.
As for clear contact, some say it is wisdom, some say it is faith, but the meaning is not in place. It is because one attains understanding from faith.
When understanding arrives and delusions are dispelled, it is called clear contact.
As for the name grasping, it can grasp and give rise to myriad wholesome [actions], and completely eliminate all evils.
It is like grasping and giving rise to subsequent karmic paths, which must be eliminated.
Due to wholesome contemplation, one attains the principle and turns to the profound, able to destroy afflictions, thus it is called increase.
However, contemplating and understanding the elimination of bonds mainly relies on single-minded recollection, thus it is called recollection as the master.
When attaining concentration, one is able to see myriad dharmas, thus it is called guidance.
